title: How to Prune a Juniper Tree

steps.title: Prune junipers annually to correct their shape.
steps.content: Prune junipers annually to correct their shape. The best time to prune your junipers is in the winter or early spring. In the springtime, it’s easier to see the general shape of the tree and cut the branches without having to worry about accidentally harming new growth. [1] X Research source Winter pruning is a great option because it ensures that the plant is pruned before new growth begins. It’s important to work before new growth begins so that you don’t have to worry about damaging new branches. This will give you the freedom to trim as needed to attain the perfect shape.

steps.title: Trim the bushes as needed in the summer if the tree loses its shape.
steps.content: Trim the bushes as needed in the summer if the tree loses its shape. After you’ve corrected the shape of the bush in the spring, you may notice that the juniper grows faster and wider during the summer. You can re-shape the tree at any time during the summer. [2] X Research source Junipers can be trimmed any time from spring until the first freeze of the year.

steps.title: Do not trim new growth during the summer.
steps.content: Do not trim new growth during the summer. When working with the tree, be careful not to cut the new growth growing from the junctions. The new growth will be soft, light green, and pliable compared to the hardwood of the old growth. Always be gentle when touching new growth, as it’s extremely delicate. [3] X Research source If you are working during the springtime, there likely won’t be much new growth to avoid.

steps.title: Avoid pruning healthy branches into the “dead zone” at the center.
steps.content: Avoid pruning healthy branches into the “dead zone” at the center. The center of the shrub doesn’t get much light, so most of the greenery in this area dies to conserve energy for the outer portion of the shrub. On a mature juniper, nothing will grow from this area, so you have to be careful not to cut too close unless you do not want the branches to grow back. [4] X Research source It’s easier to see the dead zone in the early spring when there isn’t much new growth. Sometimes, if the juniper is very mature, the dead zone will be extremely large. If the dead zone makes up the majority of the plant, dig up the juniper and replant a new shrub in its place.

steps.title: Make cuts at the junctions of the branches.
steps.content: Make cuts at the junctions of the branches. In all varieties of junipers, new growth comes from points in the tree where the branches split into 2-3 smaller branches, called junctions. When pruning the tree, try to make cuts as close to the junctions as possible to encourage more new growth throughout the year. [5] X Research source After you trim the branches to the junctions, keep an eye out for new growth.

steps.title: Cut out dead or damaged limbs using loppers to encourage new growth.
steps.content: Cut out dead or damaged limbs using loppers to encourage new growth. You may notice that some of the branches of the tree are brown and stiff. Take a pair of loppers, which are a type of gardening scissor with long handles, and cut all dead or damaged limbs into the dead zone. This will give new growth space to form! [6] X Research source In this case, it’s okay to cut into the dead zone because the branches are already dead, and there will be more space for new growth to expand on the outer area of the bush.

steps.title: Thin out creeping junipers by removing center branches.
steps.content: Thin out creeping junipers by removing center branches. Creeping and semi-upright junipers can have very thick dead zones that need to be thinned out. Use a pair of pruners or loppers to cut 30% of the central limbs out of the tree, opting for the most mature branches. Cut these branches into the dead zone to prevent them from growing back. [7] X Research source Doing this helps to prevent disease in the bush and allows more light to reach the buds at junctions toward the center of the tree. After the initial thinning, creeping and semi-upright junipers can be pruned as normal.

steps.title: Trim top branches using loppers to shape the tree.
steps.content: Trim top branches using loppers to shape the tree. Many junipers grow laterally, with branches shooting off to the sides, but some may have branches growing upwards. Use the loppers to cut the branches to about 1 inch (2.5 cm) outside of the dead zone to encourage more upward growth. [8] X Research source If you can’t find a junction, simply cut the branch to match the overall shape and height of the bush.

steps.title: Prune side branches by 1/4 of their length if they stick out from the bush.
steps.content: Prune side branches by 1/4 of their length if they stick out from the bush. The side branches take up the most space on an overgrown juniper. Use pruning scissors or hand pruners, which have shorter handles than loppers, to shorten the branches to a junction where the branch splits. You can cut up to a third of the branch without damaging its growth. [9] X Research source For example, if the length of a protruding branch is 24 inches (61 cm), you should prune 6 to 8 inches (15 to 20 cm) off of the branch.

steps.title: Tie sagging branches to the center of the shrub to secure them.
steps.content: Tie sagging branches to the center of the shrub to secure them. Even after pruning the side branches by a quarter or third, they can still sag and stick out from the tree. Use twine or tree ties to secure the branches to the center of the tree. Tie the twine around the branch and then secure it to the middle of the shrub. [10] X Research source Do not use wire to do this unless you are also using tree straps around the branches. Wire will rub against them. Tree ties tend to be sturdier than twine, but they’re more expensive. You can find them at most home improvement stores or garden centers. After a year, you will need to remove the ties, and the branches should remain in place without the ties.
